messageBody:
Neil Swingler wrote:
> The problem with putting the assert in the mock is that if the mock never
> gets called, the assert
> doesn't happen and the test still passes.

that's why the expectations in the mock objects library have implemented
a Verifiable interface almost since the beginning. We've got a helper
class to verify any appropriate fields.

> I use my own Mock object framework where I maintain a queue of expected
> calls. Each mock method
> invocation picks an invocation handler off the list and executes it. At the
> end of the test, I assert that all
> the expected mock method invocations have happened. See:
> http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?MockObjectsByDelegate

Our dynamic mock library is slowly stabilising and covers much of the
same ground. There's a parallel effort in the dot net world with
interesting quirky differences between the two environments.

Steve
